Master Theorem 1

[Neapolitan 2.8]

  • Let a, b, and c be nonnegative constants.
  • The solution to the recurrenceÂ $T (1)=1$, andÂ $T(n)=aT(\frac n c)+bn$, forÂ n>1Â forÂ nÂ a power ofÂ cÂ is
    • $T(n)=O(n)$, if $a<c$
      • a=3, b=4 â†’ n â‡’ $\frac n 3, \frac n 3$
    • $T(n)=O(n \log n)$ ifÂ $a=c$
    • $T(n) = O(n \log_c a)$ ifÂ a > c
      • $a=4, c=2$ë©´? â†’ $O(n^{\log_2 4})$
      • a>cì´ë©´ log_c a > 1ì´ê²Œ ë¨
        • $O(n \log n)$ vs $O(n^{1.00000000001})$
        • $\lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}{\frac {f(n)}{g(n)}} = \infty, c, 0$

o(n) < O(n \log n) < O(n \log_c a)

$T(n) = T(\frac n 5) + T(\frac 3 4 n) + bn$

Prove this by induction!

  • Avoid divided-and-conquer if, for exampleâ€“
    • An instance of size n is divided into two or more instances each almost of sizeÂ n.
    • An instance of size n is divided into almostÂ nÂ instance of sizeÂ $\frac n c$, whereÂ cÂ is a constant.
  • The divide-and-conquer strategy often leads to efficient algorithms, although not always!

Master Theorem 2

212p

Theorem

if $T(n) \leq a \cdot T(\frac n b) + O(n^d) $ for $a \geq 1, b>1$ and $d \geq 0$

â†’ then

$T(n) = O(n^d \log n) $ if $a = b^d$

$T(n) = O(n^d) $ if $a < b^d$

$T(n) = O(n^d \log n) $ if $a > b^d$

divide and conquer : linear timeì´ë¼ëŠ” ë³´ì¥ì€ ì—†ë‹¤.

[ALG] 3.4. Miscellaneous (1)

Finding the Closest Pair of 2D Points

1. ë‚´ìš©

[J. Kleinberg and E. Tardos, Algorithm Design, Addison Wesley, 2005. 5.4]

  • Problem

    • GivenÂ nÂ points in the plane, find the pair that is closest together.

      n

  • Notation
  • NaÃ¯ve algorithm
    • Compute the distance between each pair of points
    • take the minimum â†’Â $O(n^2)$ time undefined

      2. Applying the Divide-and-Conquer Strategy

  • [Shamos and Hoey]
  • Simple assumption for an easy explanation
    • No two points inÂ PÂ have the sameÂ _x_coordinate or the sameÂ _y_coordinate.
  • General idea
    • [Preprocessing]
      • Build a listÂ PxÂ in which all the points inÂ PÂ have been sorted by increasingÂ _x_coordinateâ†’Â $O(n \log n)$
      • Build another listÂ PyÂ in which all the points inÂ PÂ have been sorted by increasingÂ _y_coordinateâ†’Â $O(n \log n)$
    • [Recursion forÂ PÂ withÂ $âˆ£Pâˆ£=n$]
      • [Divide] PartitionÂ PÂ into two subsetsÂ QÂ andÂ RÂ â†’Â O(n)
      • [Conquer] Find the closest pairs inÂ QÂ andÂ R, respectivelyâ†’Â $2T(\frac n 2)$
      • [Combine] Use this information to get the closest pair in Pâ†’Â O(n)
      • Time-complexity
        • $O(n \log n) + T(n)$ whereÂ $T(n) = cn +2T(n/2) â†’ O(n \log n)$
  • The stage [Divide]: PartitionÂ PÂ into two subsetsÂ QÂ andÂ R.
    • CreateÂ QÂ andÂ R, where
      • Q: the set of points in the firstÂ  $\lceil(\frac n 2)\rceil$positions of the listÂ $P_x$Â (the â€œleft halfâ€),
      • R_R_: the set of points in the finalÂ $\lfloor(\frac n 2) \rfloor$positions of the listÂ $P_x$Â (the â€œright halfâ€).
    • Furthermore, createÂ $Q_x, Q_y, R_x$, andÂ $R_y$, where
      • $Q_x$ consisting of the points inÂ QÂ sorted by increasingÂ _x_coordinate,
      • $Q_y$Â consisting of the points inÂ QÂ sorted by increasingÂ _y_coordinate,
      • $R_x$Â consisting of the points inÂ RÂ sorted by increasingÂ _x_coordinate,
      • $R_y$ consisting of the points inÂ RÂ sorted by increasingÂ _y_coordinate.
    • âœ“ Can be done inÂ $O(n)$
  • The stage [Conquer]: Find the closest pairs inÂ QÂ andÂ R, respectively.
    • Recursively determine a closest pairÂ $(q_0, q_1)$Â of points inÂ Q
    • Recursively determine a closest pairÂ $(r_0, r_1)$Â of points inÂ R.
      • Can be done inÂ $2T(\frac n 2)$.
  • The stage [Combine]: Use the obtained info. to get the closest pair inÂ P.
    • Question : are there pointsÂ $q \in Q, r \in R$Â for whichÂ $d(q,r)<\delta$?
      • How can we answer this question in linear time?
    • [Fact 1] (Why?)
      • if thereÂ $âˆƒqâˆˆQ,râˆˆRÂ $for whichÂ $d(q,r)<\delta$
      • then each ofÂ q,rÂ lies within a distanceÂ $\delta$Â of $L$
    • [Fact 2]
      • $âˆƒqâˆˆQ,râˆˆR$Â for whichÂ $d(q,r)<\deltaâŸºÂ âˆƒs,sâ€²âˆˆS$Â for which $Â d(s,sâ€²)<Î´$

      • $x^*$: the x-coordinate of the rightmost point inÂ Q
      • $\delta=min(d(q_0^,q_1^),d(r_0^,r_1^))$

    • [Fact 3]
      • ifÂ $s, s^{â€˜ } \in S$Â have the property thatÂ $d(s, s^{â€˜})<\delta$, thenÂ $s, s^{â€˜}$Â re within 15 positions of each other in the sorted listÂ $S_y$
        • $S_y$Â : the list consisting of the points inÂ SÂ sorted by increasingÂ _y_coordinate.
        • Each box contains at most one point ofÂ S. (Why?)
        • If two points inÂ SÂ are at least 16 positions apart inÂ $S_y$Â , â€¦

    • [merge] :Â O(n)

      O(n)

      1. For eachÂ $s \in S_y$Â , compute its distance to each of the next 15 pts inÂ $S_y$
      2. LetÂ $s, s^{â€˜}$Â be the pair achieving the minimum of these distances

CompareÂ $d(s, s^{â€˜})$Â withÂ $Î´$
